title: 105_hr3032
content: The Act titled "Construction Subcontractors Payment Protection Enhancement Act of 1998" mandates additional responsibilities for the Administrator for Federal Procurement Policy. Section 6(d) of the Office of Federal Procurement Policy Act is amended to establish Government-wide policies for timely payment of contractors, subcontractors, and suppliers through the Federal Acquisition Regulation. This includes statutes such as the Prompt Payment Act, the Miller Act, and the Federal Acquisition Streamlining Act of 1994. The Government-wide Federal Acquisition Regulation will be revised to implement amendments within 120 days of the Act's enactment, with a 60-day public comment period. Final regulations will be published within 180 days and become effective 30 days after publication. Additionally, related amendments to the Miller Act will be made. The Miller Act is being amended to improve payment bond protection by equalizing the amount of the payment bond to the performance bond, extending protection to all subcontractors and suppliers, and specifying conditions for progress payments. Regulations will be revised within 120 days of the Act's enactment with a 60-day public comment period. The Miller Act is being amended to extend payment bond protection to all subcontractors and suppliers, with specific conditions for progress payments. The Miller Act is being amended to include new provisions for payment bond protection, requiring waivers to be in writing and specifying modernized methods for serving payment bond claims. The Miller Act is being amended to eliminate delays in payment bond protection and discourage frivolous payment bond litigation. The amendments include provisions for proof of receipt through various delivery services and allowing suits to proceed even if filed before the expiration of a 90-day period after the last labor or material supply. The Miller Act is being amended to discourage frivolous payment bond litigation by allowing courts to award court costs, attorneys' fees, and interest to the prevailing party in a suit if the suit is deemed frivolous or groundless. Interest awarded shall be calculated accordingly. The Miller Act is amended to allow courts to award court costs, attorneys' fees, and interest to the prevailing party in frivolous payment bond litigation. Contracting officers are responsible for obtaining and ensuring the payment bond remains in effect during the contract administration. The Miller Act is amended to allow courts to award court costs, attorneys' fees, and interest in payment bond litigation. Contracting officers must ensure the payment bond remains effective during the contract administration. If the bond is not in effect due to the officer's failure, the court may authorize a lawsuit against the United States for the amount that would have been sued for.
